So I haven't (publicly) written here in the longest time. I remember the days when it was routine for me to come home, sit down in front of my laptop and chronicle my day and thoughts in a blog entry. That was ruined by the rise of Twitter and micro-blogging, which reduced lengthy and thoughtful blog entries to 140-character-long blurbs. Then along came Instagram, which reduced blurbs about thoughts and feelings to pictures and captions, only posted on special events. And now, it's Snapchat, random 10-second captures of our days, which disappear in 24 hours. Our attention spans are getting shorter and shorter. Not that I'm fucking deep or anything, I can't even be bothered much with any of my social media platforms anymore. LOL social media just reminds me of the whole Essena O'Neill thing. As if she "exposed" things about social media that were unknown??? Don't even get me started *eye roll*

Now I can't even remember why I clicked on 'post an entry' in the first place. I'm rambling. My Livejournal is basically just random shit for me to read years down the road. I read old blog entries and I'm like nah, can't relate. Who was I??? What was all this crap about ~love~ and shit? What kind of weakling wrote all this drivel???

My stomach won't shut up. I'm not even hungry. Okay I'll be back to write an actual update about my life so that I and I alone can read it five years down the road and scoff at how naive I was back in 2015. Goodbye!
I'm falling in love with one of my best friends and it feels amazing

Okay I'm aware this is fucking stupid but I really get way too many repeated questions because people are either too lazy to scroll or the answers are buried underneath hundreds of others, so here goes! Will update this accordingly. 1. How old are you? I was born on 21 February 1991, so as of 2016, I'm 25. 2. Where are you studying/where have you studied? I went to primary school at CHIJ Kellock, secondary school at Crescent Girls' School, JC for a year at St Andrew's Junior College, then I did Mass Communication at Ngee Ann Poly, before coming here to the UK to study philosophy at Durham University. 3. Why did you leave JC? I didn't feel that what I was studying was relevant to what I wanted to do in the future (marketing/PR), so I left to do mass comm. 4. Why theguiltshow? Guilt Show is an album by The Get Up Kids. I really liked them when I was 14, still do. 5. What is your Instagram/Twitter/YouTube/tumblr/whatever else? Everything is theguiltshow except for YouTube: sophisticatedsavage. 6. How tall/heavy are you? 1.7m, 52-55kg on average (I think, haven't weighed myself in a while). 7. What is your sexual orientation? I am a full on lesbian. I don't find guys attractive. 8. When did you know you were gay? Aside from early encounters and experimentation, the very first at age 9, the first time I was fully aware of my feelings for a girl and recognised that as being gay was when I was 13. 9. What is your clothing/shoe/bra size? UK 8 for clothes, US9/euro 40 for shoes and 34DD. 10. Do you have any siblings? I have a sister who is three years younger than I am. 11. *insert question asking something along the lines of I am confused am I gay or straight I like looking at pretty girls blah blah* Take it easy, no one is forcing you to choose a label. You never have to if you don't want to or if you can't figure it out. Just go with the flow and do what makes you happy or what feels good, as long as you're not hurting anybody. Stop stressing out, it's not a big deal.

12. Are you a virgin? L O L. Virginity is a social construct which I do not subscribe to. 13. *insert question seeking advice re: anything to do with love, friends, etc* I am the world's worst person to go to for advice right now because I really have no patience for emotions of any sort. My advice to you will always be: just don't give a fuck, it's easy. Just do what makes you happy. Life's too short to give a shit. Stop worrying. It's your life, live it the way you want to. I don't really understand or have the patience for anyone who can't feel the same way so if you don't or can't feel this way, I'm really not someone you should be going to for advice. 14. MBTI/enneagram type? MBTI: ESTP Enneagram: 7w8 sp or 8w7 sx

It's a beautiful day and all I can think about when I look outside is how your arms used to provide the warm embrace I now get from only the sun. I feel myself forgetting you; I feel your light going out like a cloud covering the sun. I don't want to forget. I'm grasping at the memories, desperately trying to remember what you smelled like, what you felt like as you stirred in your sleep, your body pressed up against mine, what warmth your eyes held as you looked into mine. I'm desperately trying to remember what love was like for me. Because it was love. Real and true. I have typed and deleted sentence after sentence, trying to define what love was exactly. All I can come up with is that love was you and me. Love was the light in your eyes, the music in your laughter. I have almost forgotten what it was like with you. I can't forget. If I do, I will truly no longer know love. My heart has become incapable of feeling or giving love. Do I even have a heart? Sometimes I put my hand to my chest and heave a sigh of relief as I feel the steady beat of my (dare I say it?) heart. I am happy enough knowing that what we had was real. I am happy knowing that we wrote such an amazing chapter together, and I can only hope that my chapter in your book will be bookmarked, dogeared, as yours will be in mine; revisited and reread until the pages wear out like those in an old book. It's the 10th of October and today would have been our fourth year. How things have changed. I am very happy now, not any more or less than when I was with you, just a very different kind of happy. I really like where I am. I know you are very happy too, and that is how I know leaving us behind was the right thing to do. I have grown so much as a person, and I have found my own way and my own happiness, all by myself. Perhaps the only thing that (ironically) bugs me is the almost complete inability to care about anything anymore. Maybe that's a good thing, since I feel nothing but happiness. I gave you my all. I hope you know that if you had never left, I would have never put our light out. I would have never given you up for anything or anyone, and I would have chosen you, over anyone and anything, every single time. I was sure to tell you every single day how much I loved you, I made sure of that. Maybe somewhere inside me I knew this would end someday, and I had hoped that you would walk away knowing that. I loved you with everything that I had, and I can say with all my heart that I am content; I have no regrets. The sun is setting and rain is falling. It's still a beautiful day. This time when the sun dips below the horizon, it will take with it all the light you've ever given me. I write this not with a heavy heart, nor with a deep longing for the past. I write this with simple gratitude. It's been over two months and not once have I let my emotions show; not once did I tell you how I felt. These are the first words I've written for you to read since you left, and these are the last words I will ever write about you. This is the last page. This is my closure. Four years ago you told me to take a leap of faith with you, and I am infinitely grateful that I did. Thank you.

We caught up over coffee. You kissed me on the cheek and told me I smelled good. I was happy. I asked, "I'm still the only one that smells like home right?"

You looked at me apologetically.

"No, you're not..."

I sat back in horror. "I'm not?!" Anger, betrayal and absolute shock coursed through my veins. After just what, a week? She smells like home already? You must really not love me.

You quietly picked up your wallet, got up and slipped out the door. I sat there, still in shock. Should I go after you?

Doing that would accomplish nothing.

I woke up. Saw your tweets. Dreams were worse than reality today, I'm still getting better. Can't say I felt anything, but can't say I felt nothing either.

The weather has been hovering around 20 degrees lately, beautiful but actually hot. Thank goodness I bought a fan on Amazon a while back. I was starting to think that I wouldn't have any use for it because it was still chilly (under 15 degrees), but in the last week the weather has really turned. Loving the sun, though. People have actually been sitting outdoors and studying in the sun. That's all so new to me because in Singapore, the only reason you'd be out in the sun STUDYING is because your mind is no more. Had my first paper yesterday, it went okay. One down, four more to go! After they're over, I still have a 4000 word essay to hand in, so... ACK I can't wait for freedom. Wish me luck!

My exams are in four days and I feel like I barely know anything about my modules. Kind of sort of really panicking now. I've been studying but it hasn't been the hyper-focused, efficient kind of studying I know myself to be capable of. Maybe it's because I study on my bed...

Just placed an order for bikinis on ASOS. I am so excited for New York and Orlando in summer. I've never been to America nor had any real desire to, but after talking about it and planning the itinerary (especially for Orlando - Universal/Magic Kingdom/Wet 'n' Wild!) I became so psyched. Tickets have already been booked! 

I've also been thinking about friendships and just life in general. I feel like my friendships back when I was a teenager were more... Authentic. I'm not in any way implying that I'm friends with fake and superficial people (because I'm not) but I definitely shared more of myself back then. I also feel like people shared a lot more with me. I feel like I hardly know anyone, but when I really think about it, I don't think anyone really knows me either. I realise I share so much less of what I feel, what's going on in my life, what I'm doing, etc. I remember being in Crescent and going to school all excited every day because I had something really important to tell my friends. Being in the same class sure helped, I guess. A few months ago I decided to play a more active part in my friendships and talk to my loved ones more (seeing as how I have a tendency to not reply texts and worse - withdraw into myself for days) but I don't know if that's making a difference. I think I've a better word for my friendships in the past: emotional. I cared more, I shared more, cried more, said more, needed more, gave more. Maybe it's just me growing up. Or becoming emotionless. Or more independent? I'm not sure what it is but I do know that tonight I miss my past and I can't wait to go back in Singapore in July and be reunited with everyone I love and miss.

Alright, back to Hume. Signing off now (how my mom ends her texts).

So the question is: what's been happening in my life lately? To be honest, I haven't felt much motivation to blog for a while now, feel like I might abandon this space altogether... And yet I am hesitant to do so, because I've had this Livejournal since 2006, and it's got all of my favourite memories, both happy and sad, in it. I will persevere. In a way not much has happened, and yet it would seem that I would have a lot to say since moving to England; it being such a big change in my life. Perhaps I should first blog about my trip back home recently. Easter break Came back from a three week trip back to Singapore two weeks ago. It's always good to be home. Before I left Singapore and moved here, I was so excited to leave the place I had grown up in and gotten bored of. A year ago, I would have died for the chance to leave boring, stuffy, hot Singapore to go anywhere and do anything a plane ride away. I'm not regretting my decision to study overseas at all, but it has given me a new appreciation and love for my home country. I mean, where else can you go out at 3am and have a nice steaming hot bowl of bak kut teh? All the shops here close at 5pm and god forbid I find any bak kut teh. The lack of food's actually been the hardest part of living abroad. Anyway my trip back this time was a surprise one, only my sister knew I was going back. I just snuck into my house with my suitcase and surprised my parents. My mom said she knew something was up. I guess moms really do know best! Their reactions were so cute and heartwarming. I've missed them in all their occasional parent annoying-ness. Finally got to cuddle my beloved Omelette again. I have plans to maybe move out to a place of my own when I go back to Singapore (if I go back), I can't wait to take him along with me. Spent my three weeks meeting up with friends (although not as many and as often as I would have liked), clubbing, drinking, EATING, sleeping, eating... God I got so fat. I ballooned in the first week I got back. My favourite part of this trip was not telling anyone I was coming back and then surprising them one by one. Their reactions were gold. Surprised my parents first, then Evia, by getting Grace to ask her to come down from her office to collect something I passed to her. She jumped back and refused to hug me. GREAT FRIEND. Then Del, who came later. Next was Nicole, at Tantric. She yelled and yelled and asked me what I was doing there. And then that night I posted pictures on Instagram so the big secret was out hahaha loved the shocked texts. Maybe I should come back secretly all the time!
Can't wait to be home again in about three months. Thank goodness time flies x

In case some of you haven't heard, recently the Health Promotion Board published an informative and unbiased FAQ regarding sexuality. Under pressure by a certain group of individuals who felt that it was "pro-LGBT" and anti-family, HPB amended its FAQ and removed the link to Oogachaga, an LGBT support group, under its "Where can my child find support in Singapore?" section. There is currently a petition going around to review the entire FAQ. Some of you may know a pastor Lawrence Khong, who is the chairman of LoveSingapore, a network of churches in Singapore. He wrote a response to HPB's FAQs on sexuality. I'm still in disbelief that such a disgusting and ignorant article was written by a Singaporean. How is this backward mindset still existing in such a technologically and economically advanced country such as Singapore? My brain just can't process what I've just read.


Dear Lawrence Khong,
Issue 1:
If a relationship in which it is impossible to procreate is "abnormal" and "unnatural", then why are infertile men and women allowed to get into relationships without anyone kicking up a big fuss? We are considered different from other animals because we have the ability to reason, so why is the argument against homosexuality the lack of ability to procreate, as though our sole purpose is to do just that? "Moral objection is based on the intrinsic physiological nature of the male and female bodies." Tell that to the tens of thousands of people who are biologically incapable of procreating. I have raised this issue multiple times with people who support your argument, but have never received a satisfactory response, or even a response at all.
I also take issue with your implication that the law sets the standard for what is moral or immoral. The law doesn't allow the import of chewing gum. Would you consider that immoral, Pastor Khong?
Issue 2:
Do you know what is "unjust and harmful"? Asking the Health Promotion Board  to include "avenues of care" like Liberty League. Browsing through their Facebook page brought up things like "sexuality gone wrong" and "sexual brokenness". Pray tell, why would you want a confused and maybe helpless young person to call an organisation which would only serve to make them feel worse about themselves? How is it helpful or beneficial to anyone to have these people call a hotline only to be told that they are sinning, or rejects, or morally wrong? Do you not worry that some of these people may hurt themselves even further emotionally by rejecting and repressing themselves, or maybe even take their own lives? Suicide rates are highest among LGBT individuals, and you want to continue to essentially tell them that they are horrible people? Now that is "unjust and harmful".
Issue 3:
Oh, I'm sorry that the word "homophobia" is "misleading and highly offensive" to you. Gay people have only been called much worse names, been bullied and made fun of their entire lives, many to the point that they have chosen to take their own lives, instead of suffer any more rejection. It breaks my heart that many have chosen this path because of societal rejection. I can't say that I'm sorry that the use of the word "homophobia" has simply rubbed you the wrong way, though. What is your mild annoyance compared to the decades of repression, bullying and hate crimes suffered by the LGBT community?
"We do not despise homosexuals or hold them in contempt. We esteem them as fellow human beings of intrinsic worth. Each one is precious, deserving respect and love, just like anyone else." Now you're just being condescending, Pastor Khong. If homosexuals are what you claim, why are you trying so hard to reject them, change them and repress them? If you respect and love someone, you don't make them suffer. You try to understand and accept them, even if it takes time.
Issue 4:
Cite your sources. Do you mean Paul Cameron's The Lifespan of Homosexuals? One only has to glance through the "research methodology" to see what is gravely flawed in this "study".
Issue 5:
"An unproven assertion that homosexuals can have long-lasting relationships"? What do you mean by long-lasting? Twenty years? Ten? Five? It only takes a simple Google search to bring up many examples of loving homosexual partners that have been together for decades. I am also interested to see what your sources are, because you haven't cited a single source for all your sweeping statements.
-
You place so much emphasis on family and the family unit. I'm assuming this means a father, a mother, and child(ren). You are a pastor, practising a religion that promotes love and acceptance. How can it be that this loving and accepting religion is so excluding of different family units (as you have implied about your religion and its values)? What about single mothers who have to bring their children up alone? Or children brought up by grandparents or aunts and uncles? They do not form traditional family units either, but I am sure that you would not reject or even say anything about these families, because what are they doing wrong, really?


The kind of Singapore I want, and I am sure many others want, is a diverse, accepting, loving and overall happy nation. Not a draconian and authoritative nation which tells its citizens who we can or cannot love. If you love this nation so much, then stop rejecting its citizens. Make a positive change and start spreading love and acceptance instead of hate and ignorance. - Take a minute to sign this petition to restore HPB's FAQs to its original, which was very helpful, completely objective and informative.

Yet another year is drawing to a close. And what a year it's been; a year of milestones. 1. Graduation
I already blogged about graduation, but thought I'd say a few more words just for this blog post. It was an incredible three year long journey in Ngee Ann Mass Comm, and I'm grateful every day that I chose that path and met the people that I did. I learned many things, academic and personal, and would gladly relive my three years, if given the chance. It's just so hard to believe that my three years there have already come to a close, because it was all I knew, lived, ate, and breathed for such a long time.
2. Phuket
The Land of Smiles indeed. My second vacation with Grace, and our last before uni. I miss the sun, sand and sea all the time. We had so much fun.
3. Uni: moving to England Probably the biggest thing that's ever happened to me. Before I came here to study, I'd never even been to England before. It's been about three months of my living there, and I love it so much. The weather, Durham... Of course there are things I miss about being home: like my friends, family, my rabbits, the convenience, the clubbing (Zouk), the food(!!!)... I've been back in Singapore for a few weeks now and it seems like nothing has changed. Although I have been very ill all throughout Christmas and now New Year's, so that hasn't been much fun at all. I've been downright miserable. However, I've had a smashing 2013, so I guess this is a small price to pay. Some pictures of Durham:
And of course, in between these milestones, I had a fantastic time with everyone I love. I'm very grateful to the friends who've stayed, the friends I grew closer to this year, and the friends I only started talking to this year. 2013 was beautiful and amazing and so colourful. I had the time of my life this year. I must say that this was a year of few tears as well. I've been really happy and fulfilled up to this point. Although 2013 is ending and 2014 is beginning in poor health for me, I can safely say that I'm truly appreciative for all the good things and people that have come my way, and I hope that 2014 will be just as good to me. After all, it is what you make of it.

I've been off for a while now, ever since I fell sick with a high fever about three weeks ago. My appetite has diminished (and if you know me you would know how big it is), I get frequent migraines, nausea, fatigue, and I even got vertigo the other day. I've been skipping classes and keeping to myself a lot. All I feel like doing is sleeping and staying in. I don't know what's wrong with me :'(

I'll probably go to the doctor later or something. I'm so goddamn tired and sick all the time. 

Enough about my physical state.

It's getting really cold here in Durham! When I first arrived in late September it was 15-18 degrees Celsius, and now it's 1-5 degrees. Amazon has been my best friend, I get everything (especially winter essentials) off there. Currently shopping for ear muffs and a rain coat, because it does rain pretty often here. I'm really happy that it doesn't storm though, because as you might already know, I'm deathly afraid of thunderstorms. I haven't experienced a single storm since I got here!! Amazing. 

Okay I'm really tired now. Will go lie down before my next class at 4pm. Ciao!

So I accidentally locked ALL my entries and made them private, and it's going to take me a pretty long time to make some of them public again (because some were originally private, so I can't mass publicise them all again) :( Anyway I'll do it really slowly, and I probably will only make entries from 2010 or 2011 onwards private (if I ever get round to it)! Hello from Durham! I know, I know. I've completely neglected this space. I'll do an update on my life here soon, but for now, let me finish part two of my Phuket post! (For my ask.fm anons :p)
Day 3: Sunday, 25 August We got up bright and early (at 6am) to get ready for our island hopping tour! The bus came to pick us up from our hotel at 7am, and we slept through the journey to the ferry terminal. So we boarded this ferry along with many other tourists, and off we went! Our first stop was Khai Nok Island, for some snorkelling and chilling. Because it wasn't accessible directly via the ferry, we had to get off the ferry and onto a long-tail boat. The one on the left is a long-tail boat Rows and rows of colourful beach chairs and umbrellas, which you could rent for like 150baht I think? And yes that's a butch and her girlfriend, from China. I thought she was cute HAHAHA Check out the colour of the sand and the water :') With her favourite 50baht grilled corn Okay so we tried to snorkle, but the waves were just too strong and there were just too many people, so we bought bread and ended up feeding the fish instead. They would just swim right up to you in schools, too cute! After about an hour or so, we got back on the boat and headed back to the ferry, where they served lunch in cute Japanese bento boxes. Then we went to some bay for snorkelling! We all got off the ferry and snorkelled in the clear waters. I can't swim, so I was kind of petrified for the first 15 minutes. I clung on to Grace for dear life, until finally the people on the ferry saw how much I was freaking out, and threw me a float HAHAHA. After that Grace taught me how to breathe through the snorkelling mask, and held my hand throughout. I calmed down, and had an amazing time snorkelling for the first time ever! We saw swordfish and all sorts of other colourful fish :) I really loved it. Next stop: Phi Phi Island. I'd heard a lot about how it was a huge tourist trap, so I wasn't expecting much. Got some chicken and basil with rice ' I was right not to expect much, most of the island consisted of stalls (which I wasn't interested in) Explored for a little while, then we went back to the ferry, which concluded our island tour. I think I enjoyed the journey back the most, it took over an hour to get back, and we just laid on the top deck, soaking up the sun. I fell asleep on Grace's lap because the sound of the waves, the sun, the incredible breeze, and the sea spray were just all so relaxing :') That was the most amazing nap. Got back to our room in time for the sunset :) That night, we got dressed up and went out for a dinner date at a restaurant called Karlsson's, which was apparently really good for its steak and Swedish food. My ribeye with gorgonzola cheese sauce, which was sooo good! Ordered some swedish meatballs to share as well Afterwards, we went to explore Bangla Road, which is where all the nightlife is! Naturally, along the streets, there were so many people advertising their bars, clubs, etc. There were also people carrying these: FUCKING SLOW LORISES OMG HOW CAN ANYTHING BE THIS CUTE AHHHHH!!!! It had little fingernails and cute little hands which would so cutely grab onto your arm or anything else on you omfg and these amazing huge, sad, wet eyes that would BEG you to take it home. Omfg I've never seen anything so cute before. It was 100baht (SGD4) to take pictures with one, and I spent SGD12 taking photos with several HAHAHA. I wanted to cry from all the cuteness. Grace bought me a rose off a street vendor (awwww) and I presented it to a slow loris, whose eyes widened in an almost crazy manner, then it slowly started moving towards it, its arms outstretched, and BAM! It suddenly grabbed my rose and tore off some petals and started eating them omfg cutest thing I've EVER SEEN. HAHAHAHAHAHHA. Mega pole dance club we went into! We ended up having drinks and talking to one of the dancers. When we asked her to give Grace a lap dance, she was so hesitant and refused to because she said if she had a boyfriend, she wouldn't want other girls to dance on him and she didn't want us to fight HAHAHAHA awww :p Also Thai girls seem to really like my boobs, they kept complimenting them and touching them HAHA. We had some beer and tequila and headed back. Spent the whole day out at sea, so we were pretty beat! Day 4: Monday, 26 August Woke up early again for horseback riding! A car came to pick us up and drove us to the place. I was really excited because when I rode on a horse for the first time when I was 11, I had such a good experience and I've always wanted to get back on a horse since! It was blazing hot that day :( we rode for about an hour and it was really fun! Maybe I should join the equestrian club here... Hmm. Anyway, we went back to our hotel. I had the most torturous ride back EVER. About 5-10 minutes into the 30 minute journey, I needed to pee really badly. I'm pretty good at holding my pee, but prior to the journey I had finished an entire cold coconut, and stupidly decided that I didn't need to visit the bathroom. So when I say I needed to pee, I mean I NEEDED TO PEE. I WAS ON THE VERGE OF PEEING IN MY PANTS. I was in actual physical pain from holding my pee in. The driver didn't really understand English, so we couldn't get him to stop and let me pee somewhere else. Also, we travelled with another couple, so I didn't want to inconvenience everyone. Eventually, I reached the point where I didn't give a fuck anymore, I just needed to pee. I ended up typing "I need to pee can you drop me somewhere" into my Google Translate app, and showed it to the driver. All he kept saying was "no toilet, no toilet" I WAS FUCKING DYING. After 20 minutes of digging my nails into my arm to keep myself from pissing my pants, we finally reached the other couple's hotel, and I bolted to the bathroom. Best pee ever. Rented a car later, and went exploring! First off we went to Phuket Town for some prawn mee. Went on nice long scenic drives :') We were looking for Freedom Beach. Apparently it's really pretty but hard to get to! I think we drove for over an hour, stopping for directions many times Hehe our rental car We found what we thought was Freedom Beach, and what everyone told us was Freedom Beach. Later on back in Singapore I found out it was called Paradise Beach :( But we had a lovely time, anyway! So it doesn't really matter :) It was a private beach, so we had to pay for entry Ordered coconuts and food to share right at the water's edge :) The beach's resident black lab? :') This cutie came to sit quietly by me when I called him over ^^ His face is all sandy because he was digging in the sand for something HAHA We stayed there and chilled for about an hour, then we left for the drive to Phromthrep Cape, famous for its sunsets. I was really determined to catch the sunset that day, so we left with enough time to drive there. It was at the southernmost tip of Phuket, so it took us a good 50 minutes' drive! Well worth it, though. We drove back and went for another dinner date, at a restaurant really near our hotel, called Da Maurizio Bar Ristorante. It's consistently named as one of Phuket's most romantic restaurants, so we knew we had to try it. The food was so amazing. I had simple beef bolognese, which was really good. Grace had vongole, which she proclaimed as the best she's ever had Then we went back to Bangla Road, where Grace had a really good night. I will say no further. Our final night in Phuket :( The next day, we woke up early and flew back to Singapore. And that was the end of our amazing second holiday together, and the last one before we started university life.

So, I'm leaving in 24 hours... My room is in a mess (as usual), but this time it's because I'm packing about half my life into just two suitcases. My heart is heavy and there are a million things I still need to pack and do but all I can do is sit here and feel sad. I mean, of course I'm excited for this new phase in life, it's just that Singapore has always been and will always be my home, and I'm actually growing up and leaving it now :'( My family, my pets, my friends, my room, the food, the convenience... Only now do I realise just how many things I'm going to be missing about Singapore.

Grace is on the plane now. I'll be seeing her in about 48 hours. Feeling excited and scared and nervous and sad all at the same time. Not looking forward to saying bye to my loved ones tomorrow... :(

Hi guys! I decided to try and be more regular with my updates heh heh. Anyway, I came back from a 5-day holiday in Phuket about a week ago. It was an amazing holiday; one last vacation/honeymoon before Grace and I leave for Durham :'(
Day 1: Friday, 23 August Our flight was at 8am, we wanted to have the whole day ahead of us when we reached! Our driver met us at the airport and took us to our hotel, See Sea Phuket. We booked the penthouse with private pool! Pool had a jacuzzi function Private balcony Upon reaching our hotel, we called for (free) breakfast to be served to our room! Eggs, toast, bacon, the like. And then we took a nap HAHAHA. I hadn't slept a wink before my flight, so I was super tired. After waking up, we decided to explore the area! Took a tuktuk to a nearby shopping mall called Jungceylon The mall was really quite big! Anyway, we went there because I got some of my facial products confiscated at the airport (because I'm dumb like that) and hence had to find replacements asap :( We ended up taking neoprints as well HAHAHA. Found a roadside market opposite the mall! Found a shop that sold shorts, and I bought 3 for 200baht, which is SGD8 wtf. We also found a travel agent and booked day tours for the next 3 days! So I got this question on ask.fm, but my answer was too long, so I thought I'd just answer it here. Q: why is it so hard to get a gap 3.6 though? my brother's in year 1 and his work looks so simple! like what exactly is hard about the masscomm course? A: Let me just say that year 1 is bullshit compared to year 3..... In year 1, I spent all my time going out and playing but in year 3 I hardly had time to eat, shit or sleep (not exaggerating). Here are all the things you need to maintain a good GPA:
  1. Consistent hard work
  2. Fully cooperative group mates
  3. Ability to multitask
  4. Ability to survive on as little sleep as possible, preferably none at all
  5. Lack of need for a social life
1) Consistent hard work This is because mass comm isn't exam-based. We are graded on one large group project which we work on through the semester, many individual assignments given throughout the semester, class participation, and exams (for some modules only). To do well for just one module, you would need to ace the exam, ace about 5 different individual assignments through the semester, and ace the group project, which may be affected by (2). Decide that you can't be bothered to do just one assignment properly, and your entire grade for the whole semester goes down. Do well for all your assignments but don't study for the exam? Your entire grade goes down. Do well for exams but didn't do your assignments properly? Your entire grade goes down. And so on and so forth. So to get a 4.0 GPA, this basically means scoring almost perfect grades for all 34 modules through 3 years, which means almost perfect scores for about 170 individual assignments, 34 group projects, and ~15 exams. Does that sound hard to you? 2) Fully cooperative group mates If you're a JC/IB kid, you wouldn't know the importance of group mates. I mean I didn't, not even during PW in JC, until I got to mass comm. You work with your group for basically 70-80% of all assignments. You're stuck with them. Firstly, you obviously don't get to pick your classmates, which means if you happen to be in a class with many lousy group mates (they have a reputation), you have to grab the good ones - fast. Those you may not even speak to socially. Let me just briefly name the types of lousy group mates. a) the freeloader (who does nothing but gets your grade), b) the boss (who bosses people around but largely does nothing), c) the idiot (who throws out lots of stupid ideas and annoys everyone) and d) the stupid one (self-explanatory). If you happen to have these people in your group, you have two options. You can TRY to force them to do their work, which means sub-standard work and a mediocre grade, or you can do all the work yourself, and let them have the grade YOU worked for. Most people go for the first. This means your entire project grade goes down, pulling your GPA down. Seeing as how there are roughly 34 group projects throughout mass comm, that's a lot of group politics to deal with. Also, working with friends isn't a good idea because relationships get strained if they're a good friend but not a good worker. 3) Ability to multitask You need some serious skills. With about 5 modules per semester, that means 5 group projects and ~25 individual assignments. Which means some of these assignment and project deadlines will fall on the same day. On the night before, especially if you're a last minute worker like most of us mass commers, you would have to work simultaneously on different assignments. In my last semester, I had up to 5 deadlines in one day. 4) Ability to survive on as little sleep as possible, preferably none at all Like I said, we would get up to 5 deadlines in a single day. We regularly stayed up nights without sleeping at all. If I recall correctly, I would pull at least one all-nighter a week. And that's not even what kills you. In one week, with up to 10 deadlines, you would be lucky to get 1-2 hours of sleep a night. And by the end of the week, with only 5-10 hours of accumulated sleep, trust me, you feel like absolute SHIT. You're falling asleep in the bus, in class, on your bed when you come home, then you'll wake up in a panic because you have 3 assignments to submit tomorrow, then you'll catch 30 mins of sleep before school, fall asleep in the bus..... etc. I was almost suicidal in February because I was so miserable from school LOL. I saw eating and sleeping as a waste of time. I did work on my bed, I ate on my bed, I slept in my bed (if I was lucky). 5) Lack of need for a social life Self-explanatory. -- I have attached screenshots of my iCal from November to February, my last semester in mass comm. Hope it gives you more insight into the life of a mass commer LOL.

I downloaded and watched Religulous today, and I must say it's an excellent documentary. It questions the arguments for religion, as well as its usefulness for the good of mankind. As you can tell from the title, it approaches religion in a mocking way, as does its host, Bill Maher, a comedian. It was absolutely hilarious and very logical. Everything that was said just resonates with me, especially this closing paragraph. The questions asked, the points made, everything was coherent, logical, and of course, funny. A must-watch for agnostics and atheists out there. And if you're religious, I'd encourage you to watch it, too. It will leave you with food for thought. I've always thought religion as a whole was dangerous and detrimental to us, and this documentary has further pushed me in that direction. Watch it with an open mind :)

I thought it was at 11am!" and I wondered how come we even thought it was at 11am. It was in the afternoon, I was sure..... Right? I took out my phone and scrolled to our e-tickets. Yeah, it says 1pm! BUT WAIT.... 1pm on the 17th of December? Today's the 20th, right? My heart stopped and I slowly scrolled down. 20th December: flight departs at 10am. We had missed our flight. At that moment, I was debating between telling Grace I had seen the flight time wrongly, or just pretending not to know anything until we reached the airport and then act shocked. After about two seconds, I very meekly told her that I'd seen the time wrongly and that we had missed our flight. Now, it's important for me to mention that I've never once missed a flight in my life, and neither has my family. They're very particular about things like these. So missing the flight was a HUGE deal for me. Grace was pissed at first, and then I started sobbing because I felt so bad and so stupid and I was worried I'd fucked up all our plans and our entire trip. Then she softened and began comforting me. I was sobbing and eating my lu rou fan at the same time, and apologising to her. In the end she kept laughing while comforting me because I must've looked like shit, eating and crying at the same time. I guess our driver was worried that I thought we were going to be late for our flight, because he asked if our flight was at 11am worriedly (we didn't have the heart to tell him the truth). Thankfully we managed to get another flight, because there's one every hour. We had to pay SGD150 each though. So we wandered around the airport, trying to use the ATM, etc. And then we realised we were going to be late for our flight(!!!) so we RAAAAAN all the way to our boarding gate, and made it 5 minutes before our plane took off, gasping and wheezing. On the plane, I put my newly-bought stuffed Totoro in the seat next to me, only to have the stewardess tell me I have to put him in the overhead compartment. I then looked at Totoro sadly and said, "No, Totoro!" and she said, "I'm sorry" to me very apologetically and I felt like an idiot... :( AAAAND we arrived in Hong Kong for part 2 of our trip! :) Got picked up by our driver and went to our hotel! Laid around for a bit before heading out to grab a bite and explore the area :) Explored the little shops in an alley near our hotel and came across many cool stores! One sold all kinds of Zippo lighters, and another sold knives (I love knives). The Zippo store's resident cat ^^ They tagged my suitcase with this HAHA. We went to buy groceries at the convenience store right next to our hotel to stock up for the next 4 nights ^^ Continued with our LOTR marathon that night! Day 5 - Friday, 21 December 2012 We were supposed to go to Ocean Park that day! But we ended up changing our plans and spent the day shopping instead! Went crazy here, the stuff is like half the price in Singapore?! Tsui Wah <3 My XO sauce noodles Amazing wings Basically we walked EVERYWHERE that day, our legs were hurting so badly by the time we got back. That's all for Days 4 and 5 :) Next up: Day 6, also the Ocean Park post! :)

My friend Derrick says love is the only war worth dying for. But every time I say, “please come back”, I feel like I'm trying to find a dirty needle in a haystack, and God knows I can’t go out like that. I suppose we wear our traumas the way the guillotine wears gravity. Our lovers’ necks are so soft. I lost my head so many times. I got sober just hoping my eyes would dry. Still, I drink so much in my sleep, I can’t sleepwalk a straight line to the guest room or collapse, hang so heavy inside her lungs. She speaks and her voice trips across her heartbeat, each word limps into the air. We are gone, she says. And I am no mortician; I have no idea how to put make-up on the dead. I have no idea how to unerase, so I just puddle at the door, my face looking like a deck of falling cards, like everything’s been playing me. We tried so hard. But when I said “give me a ring”, she thought I meant a call. Now I haven’t had her number for two years. We’ve been saying how many times are we going to keep cutting these red flags into valentines. You know, all those wars we fought have turned our shine into rust, we can’t even touch each other’s hearts without a tetanus shot. We can’t begin to remember how we forgot there is no shelter in the womb. The heart forms long before the ribcage. My mother swore she could feel me kicking weeks before my feet formed. That’s how hard my heart beat — and it still does. They say the womb is where we learn love is knowing the cord that feeds you could at any moment wrap around your neck. I hold my breath for the entire 56 seconds it takes her to walk to the window to stare at the road to tell me she has nothing left to tell me, we are done, carrying our level heads in our tornado chests. For the first time, I know she is right. As the dawn, after our first date, we were so young, and I hadn’t written an honest love poem yet. I hadn’t met anyone I could fall so hard for ‘til the night we kissed on our skateboards, she teased me for going so slow. I said I never want to catch up with the letting go. I want the plead in my throat to forever anger my spine and the seams of your slippers, love, even when the dove crashed through the window, even when our friends said, you can call it love, but you know Einstein called himself a pacifist when he built the bomb. When they ask why we stayed together for so long I say, I don’t know. I just know that we cried at the exact same time in every movie. I know we blushed everyday for the first two years. I know I always stole the covers and she never woke me up. I know the exact look on her face, the first night she used my toothbrush. The next day, I brushed my teeth like thirtysome times, ‘cause I didn’t want to let her go. You have to understand when it hurt to love her, it hurt the way the light hurts your eyes in the middle of the night, but I had to see, even through the ruin, if what we were burying were seeds. There were so many plants in our house, you could rake the leaves even through that winter when I was trying to make angels in the snow of her cold shoulder. She was still leaving love notes in my suitcase; I’d always find them. The day before I left, I remembered a story her mother told me. She said, Andrea, when Heather was a little girl, she couldn’t fall asleep without tying a string to her finger all night long, she’d give that string the tiniest tug to make sure I was still there. And I’d tug back. That was love. That was love. As easy as that. Sometimes. Sometimes.

It's been about a week since my last paper, putting an end to my three years in Ngee Ann Polytechnic and in Mass Communication. How does it feel? It feels amazing. I'm finally free from the sleepless nights, the waking up in panic to complete unfinished work, the last minute touches on a research paper, the frantic editing of Powerpoint slides before a presentation/pitch, the extreme lethargy after 36 hours without sleep, the juggling of five different assignments from five different modules in one night, the endless deadlines, the non-existent weekends, the completely reversed sleep cycles, the sometimes unpleasant group members, and finally, the politics and drama in Mass Comm (this list is non-exhaustive). For both of my exam papers I pulled all nighters; one night at Liat Starbucks with Evia and Ashley, and we went straight to school for our 9am paper from there. The other one I studied 12 hours before and hence didn't—and couldn't—catch a wink of sleep. What's new? Come to NP's Mass Comm and you will find that sleep will become a rarely-enjoyed luxury (you'd be lucky to catch 4 hours a night). Procrastination will become your middle name. Multi-tasking will become second nature to you. Would I recommend my course? I don't know. Course structure wise we did learn a lot of things, particularly hands-on activities like working a film camera, designing a poster in Photoshop, web design, becoming a radio DJ, designing a newspaper/magazine from scratch, etc. Of course there were content heavy and writing intensive modules (like Media Law, Contemporary Issues, Mass Media in Singapore and Asia, etc) as well. However, I don't really feel like I benefited greatly in an academic or intellectual sense from the course. It just wasn't very intellectually challenging the way math was, for instance. I'm not saying I did very well (in fact, my GPA is mediocre at best), I'm just saying it's easy to do well if you work hard and are consistent for every module. It doesn't really require intelligence, not in the way physics or math does anyway. (Okay I realise this sounds like sour grapes but I assure you it's not LOL). Overall, it's great if you aspire to work in the media industry! You learn a lot of technical and practical skills, that's for sure. One other thing to consider is the goddamn politics. Before I entered the course I heard so much about it. MCM has the bitchiest people, the most politics, blah blah. I took it all with a pinch of salt. When I entered MCM, I was like where's the politics? I made so many good friends, we had so much fun and shared so much laughter together. Little did I know that was something reserved only for Year One. You start out with so many friends. Everyone's cool, everyone's so nice, everyone's great! The workload was light and manageable, you go out every day with your friends and you fool around most of the time. In Year Two, that's when you more or less know who your friends really are. You drift from those you used to hang out with every day, you realise some people are just that hard to tolerate, and word starts to spread about the freeloaders (people who don't do their share of the work), the weird people, the temperamental people... Your circle of friends shrinks. The workload gets heavier, and you realise it's impossible to not stay up all night to complete your work. Year Three was when I really finally saw why everyone had warned me about the politics. The workload is craaaazy intense and I'm not even exaggerating. All the deadlines fall in the same week (that's at least five) and you sleep, eat and breathe schoolwork. I even dreamt about schoolwork numerous times and then I woke up and had to really do it. Fun. Eating becomes a waste of time, sleeping becomes absolutely impossible. Coffee and Red Bull become your best friends. Dressing up for school becomes ridiculous because who can be fucked when you have three deadlines on the same day and you haven't slept? With the intense workload, the claws and fangs come out. There's so much bitching, so much backstabbing. You realise many of your friends can in fact keep their personal and professional lives separate. Do your work, or you will get peer evaluated by your group mates. So many fake smiles, fake niceties, and then literally turning away to roll your eyes or bitch to your friend on Skype. I consider myself lucky I haven't been the target or centre of any of this drama. It's ridiculous. Don't come to MCM if you can't handle this shit man. If you're weird you'd better have a loud personality and insane self-confidence to go along with it. You will get made fun of openly, and shunned. So many people in MCM are outspoken, outgoing and have a loud personality and they will climb all over you. Okay I made my course sound extremely horrible and scary. Well, it wasn't to me. I must say even after all the hard work and politics (which I rather enjoyed witnessing), I enjoyed myself and met some very amazing people who are among my best friends now. I don't regret it at all. Although it has probably made me a bitchier and nastier person, this is what I will need if I desire to work in the media industry. NP MCM: real life experience. I actually miss it already. Feels kind of weird not having anything to worry about. Ah, sweet freedom! I've had a fantastic week, what with the end of poly life, Grace's birthday, and then mine. Updates soon! :)

Day 2 - Tuesday, 18 December 2012
We tried waking up early for breakfast but being pigs, we only woke up in time for brunch. Every morning we would bicker over who would get out of bed to shower first, and once we were in the shower, we would bicker over who would step out first :p Perhaps one of the hardest things in life is stepping out from a steaming hot shower and into a cold air-conditioned room in winter. We had two bowls of lu rou fan, two bowls of egg soup, two cups of pearl milk tea and one large oyster omelette, all for about SGD8, if I remember correctly. Food in Taipei is so cheap! The empty streets of Ximending in the day! #OOTD LOL Hehe So our plan for the day was to shop. We decided to head to Wufenpu, a wholesale market. Took a cab down. Unfortunately we went too early (around 12pm) and most shops were still closed, so we decided to head elsewhere.
Bicycles for rent Decided to take the MRT to our next destination! Their single-trip tickets are little plastic coins you slot into the gantry (forgot to take a picture of them), so cute. Our next stop was this store! It's an LGBT store selling clothes, binders, DVDs, and a lot of other stuff (including sex toys) ;) The sales assistant/owner of the shop was damn cute because she grew up in LA (we found out later) and hence had the cutest accent and once she started speaking, Grace looked at me because she knew I'd like it HAHAHA. They had super exotic pets like tortoises, spiders, baby hedgehogs, frogs, and sugar gliders! Cutie kitty sleeping Took the train back to our hotel, where we dropped off our stuff and I put my camera battery back in :p Pictures from here on are from my camera! Yes, we have couple shoes (I bought them for us in Korea in March) We went shopping around Ximending! Guess what we were eating? Ah Zong Mian Xian! The famous mee sua place. MUST TRY! Omg (this was SGD1.80) Hot mee sua on a cold rainy day :) There are no tables, so you just stand around and eat, but that doesn't stop the crowd! Korean seafood pancake! The Red House. There are supposedly many gay bars here, but we didn't see any?? Omfg I fucking love this!!!! It's roasted mochi on a stick, with a milky sweet sauce. THIS IS TO DIE FOR. It's hot and crispy on the outside and sticky on the inside, and the sweetness of the sauce perfectly complements the plainness of the mochi! Then we got tired and decided to buy supper and head back to the hotel. Fave eatery Lu rou fan while watching LOTR :) (we had a LOTR marathon every night during our trip!) This doesn't look like much, but it's the best fucking shaved ice ever. The ice is milky and sweet and so fine (like ice cream), topped with mango ice cream and generous chunks of sweet mango. Fuck me. As you can see, we ate A LOT. There is no shortage of food in Taiwan. I seriously never felt full and I was always starving, like not even just peckish, but STARVING. I felt my stomach growling perpetually and had to eat to satisfy it for maybe 30 minutes at most... It was insane. Let me summarise the things we ate that day: Lu rou fan, pearl milk tea, egg soup, oyster omelette, cheese and pork croissant, pork sandwiches, mee sua, Korean pancake, roasted mochi, lu rou fan (for the second time), and shaved ice. Everyone on Twitter and Instagram kept expressing jealousy because of our food pictures HAHAHA. Okay that's it for Day 2! More next time :)

Day 1 - Monday, 17 December 2012: I woke up very, very excited. My first trip with Grace! Our flight was at 8am, so I spent the night before frantically packing and texting Grace to tell her how excited I was. Packed my makeup and my toiletries and all my last minute stuff, then took a cab at 6am to Serene Centre, where she picked me up and we shared a very quiet car ride with secret smiles, and the air was heavy with excitement :) :) :) Reached the airport and had a quick breakfast of KFC, then we went in and boarded our flight! As I said in my previous visuals post, we stopped over at HK first before our connecting flight! Love the Hong Kong airport, it's so huge and spacious and naturally well-lit. One downside: you have to walk fucking AGES to get to your gate. HATED this, especially towards the end of our trip. Tell you why in another post :p Played with gadgets while waiting Yay for dishevelled from a flight couple Eating dimsum By the way my standard luggage weight is always around 20kg. This increased later on LOL. Alright so we took our connecting flight and landed in Taipei!!!!! :) So exciting! I've been to Taiwan twice before, and loved it each time, so I couldn't wait to bring Grace around (she's never been there before this trip)! Yay our driver came to pick us up in a BMW, no less! Ridin' in comfort ^^ I was very excited about our hotel! I had done a lot of research on hotels prior to the trip and I booked a very well-reviewed hotel in a prime location, at a good price, too! They won some travel award. Also, it's a boutique hotel, extremely quirky and well-designed :) Each room has a different theme, and as you can see, ours is bicycle-themed! Grace was in a biking phase just before the trip, so naturally she was very excited about this. That's Grace's tiny suitcase (she insists mine is ginormous) which is like 2/3 of mine, and weighed like 4-5kg less LOL. I always overpack, but it's safer to overpack than underpack ;) OH FUCK FORGOT TO MENTION THAT. I FUCKING. FORGOT. MY. BRAS. HAHAHAHAHA. The only one I had was the one I was wearing..... (I bought two on my trip) HAHAHAHA STILL CAN'T BELIEVE I FORGOT ALL MY BRAS. So much for overpacking lol. Very small, clean, and cosy. No windows, but we didn't mind! It just added to the cosiness :) Even the floor was textured like metal ramps! What lovely attention to detail. If you're interested, we stayed in CityInn Hotel Plus - Ximending. We paid around $112 per night, for two people! Really good deal, I'm so pleased with myself (I did all the research and booked all the hotels for us hehe). Also service was really good, we left cup noodles lying around and housekeeping stacked it nicely and even gave us chopsticks!!! We didn't even request for them. The location was amazing, it was literally just across the road from TWO of the MRT entrances, both equal distance from the hotel, which were also underpasses to the heart of Ximending itself! You can get there in about three to five minutes of walking. Ximending is supposedly the trendiest shopping district where all the young people hang out! Also I read that it's the LGBT district hehe. Saw many, many butches though LOL Taiwan is lesbian capital. Took the train on our first night! Where were we going? :p Took some time/walking/asking for directions to find the place Some freshly-made buns we stopped to try! Our first destination: Shida Night Market I'v been to a few of the other night markets previously but I remember only this one stood out, because of its shopping. If you didn't already know, night markets are a must visit in Taiwan! If not for its amazing variety of delicious and very cheap street food, for its ambience! It's something that's very Taiwanese and everyone should experience while in Taiwan. I feel that Shida is more for young people because it's very near a university, so the prices and clothes are student-friendly. Lots of hip little boutiques, cafes, and not to mention street food!!! *__* (my favourite part about Taiwan) MY ABSOLUTE FAVOURITE DISH!!!!11!1!!!!!!!!!!11!!!!!!!!!1 Lu fucking rou fan. YUM. Also a must-try. So we browsed the stalls, bought lots of food from different vendors, shopped a little, and decided to set off to a place I've read a lot about that was in the vicinity. Took us A LOT of walking in alleys and asking for directions to find it! But it was worth it :)
Minimal Cafe! It's a CAT CAFE!!! Smells just a teeny bit like cat piss, but it's mild enough to ignore :p SO many cats just roaming around, some napping, and some playing with people! Cutie patootie Okay I think we were really tired from flying and also shopping, so we took a cab back to the hotel. But before going up, we stopped at Family Mart (literally 5m from the hotel) to buy snacks! And cup noodles. Family Mart is like 7-11. It's everywhere. And that's all we did for Day 1! Not much, because as I said, we were kind of tired already. I'll continue the rest another day. Also, we filmed vlogs!
